Why should leaseholders have to pay at all? What about those who have already spent thousands on waking watches, higher insurance premiums and the installation of fire alarms? And who is going to enter into a long, uncertain and expensive legal process? This is not fair. https://t.co/RS3CWJsPXO

10. So instead of offering webinars to businesses whose job has been made harder, when is the Government going to  address the fundamental cause of all of this and start building a new and better trading relationship with the EU?  /ends

9. The trouble is that these things won’t deal with the problem, namely that checks, bureaucracy, rules of origin, paperwork and extra costs are a fundamental part of trading with the EU as a third country (which is what we now are).

8. And the Government’s response? "We know that some businesses are facing challenges with specific aspects of our new trading relationship, and that's why we are operating export helplines, running webinars with experts and offering businesses support..”

7. Peter Cowgill said "I actually think it was not properly thought out. All the spin that was put on it about being free trade and free movement has not been the reality…. the new system and red tape just slows down efficiency….”
6. And this week, the boss of one of Britain's big retailers - JD Sports - is reported as saying that Brexit has turned out to be considerably worse than he feared.

5. The British Chambers of Commerce have said "with data from the first year of the TCA now available, the UK is trading less with the EU, than it was three years ago. This gap is not currently being made up by trade with the rest of the world."

4. According to new figures from the ONS, UK exports of goods to the EU in 2021 were 12% lower compared with 2018 - ie the last year before the impact of Covid and Brexit stockpiling - whereas exports to the rest of the world were only about 6% lower -ie half that amount.
3. The Public Accounts Committee has found that “UK businesses face additional administration and cost when trading with the EU.”
2. In recent weeks we have seen more and more evidence of the adverse impact that the UK’s new trading relationship with the EU is having on British businesses and exports.
1. After the Brexit deal was signed, Boris Johnson infamously claimed that there would be "no non-tariff barriers" on trade with the EU. It wasn’t true.

On Monday, after paying tribute to Jack Dromey, I asked Michael Gove if he will guarantee that leaseholders will not have to meet the cost of other non-cladding fire safety defects. The reply I got shows  why we have to go on campaigning. @LeedsCladding @ukcag @LKPleasehold https://t.co/i7QIBxPcUG
My reflections on yesterday’s cladding announcement and why we need to keep up the pressure. ⁦@LeedsCladding⁩ ⁦@ukcag⁩ ⁦@LKPleasehold⁩ https://t.co/tjh4AT8jAM

8. These are all reasons why we must continue to campaign until leaseholders know for sure that they will be protected from all these costs and the buildings they live in can finally be made safe. @LeedsCladding @ukcag @LKPleasehold

7. Getting money out of the building safety fund is far too slow and complicated. And the longer buildings remain unsafe, the longer leaseholders will have to continue paying waking watch and higher insurance bills while their flats remain worthless.

6. The warnings to developers may sound tough but what action will follow if they don’t respond? And will all this be enough to persuade lenders, insurers and surveyors to say that flats now have value again and can be sold?
5. Developers and freeholders have had four years to meet these costs. Why does the Government think that they will now suddenly come forward and do so in the next two months?

4. Thousands of leaseholders have already had such bills and they are sitting on desks or in drawers. Until they know for sure that they won’t have to pay them, then all the worry and distress that they are experiencing will continue.

3. Michael Gove said that leaseholders would be protected from forfeiture or eviction arising from historic fire safety costs, but he couldn’t answer my question about whether this would extend to protection against bankruptcy as a result of bills that leaseholders can’t pay.

2. Government will now cover the cost of replacing dangerous cladding in all blocks over 11m. They have promised to provide statutory protection for leaseholders against having to bear any of the costs of other fire safety defects, but we don’t yet know what form this will take.

1. Reflections on yesterday’s cladding announcement. There are things in it to welcome, including abandoning the idea of a loan scheme for leaseholders in blocks below 18m, new guidance to help assess the fire safety risk in buildings and indemnifying building assessors.

A reminder of the Government’s announcement almost a year ago promising to “bring an end to unsafe cladding with multi-billion pound intervention”.  Today’s announcement by Michael Gove is a sign that we still have some way to go.  Meanwhile leaseholders wait in fear and debt. https://t.co/y0dauSnqc5

If this is true then it’s some progress. Leaseholder loans were totally unfair and wouldn’t have worked. But ministers still haven’t grasped the problem of other fire safety defects - like missing fire breaks - discovered in many buildings. You can’t make a building half safe. https://t.co/KjYKpfbsGR

6. Finally, this was the big test of whether levelling up meant anything. Today shows that the Government has failed this test.

5. Leeds has long needed a rapid transit system and we are the largest city in Europe without one. The plan talks about £200m to develop proposals and start work, but then says that the total cost for the initial network will be £2 billion. Where is the money for this?

4.And what about Leeds station which is almost at capacity?  Its expansion plans depended on HS2 arriving from the south to form a T-station which would have freed up capacity coming into Leeds west/east and east/west. Now all we’re getting is yet another study.

3. While there will be a high speed line from Birmingham to East Midlands Parkway, despite some of the briefing I can find no sign of firm plans for the line between Leeds and Sheffield. In any event, that still leaves a great big hole in the middle of where HS2 East used to be.

2. Ministers say “the full HS2 and Northern Powerhouse Rail schemes as originally proposed would not enter service until the early to mid-2040s” as if this was somehow a justification for scrapping them. This was meant to be an investment for 100 years or more.
1.Not only has the Prime Minister broken his word that HS2 East and Northern Powerhouse Rail would be built in full, but the more I read of the Integrated Rail Plan, the less integrated it appears.
The Prime Minister repeatedly pledged that HS2 and Northern Powerhouse Rail would be built in full. Today that promise has been broken. Leeds and the North have been betrayed. https://t.co/A67Xn6GAMy

10. So what we now need is for some calm rational common sense to be applied by both sides in finding a way forward.   /ends

9. The Government’s wish to have a continuing punch-up with the European Union is, however, not in anybody’s interests. Brexit has happened. The question now is what kind of future relationship we’re going to have with our biggest and important trading partners.

8. As for democratic consent, the protocol allows the NI Assembly to decide whether it wants these trading arrangements to continue or not. In other words, if the elected representatives of NI think that part of protocol isn’t working, they can vote to end it.

7. You could use the Joint Committee to agree a clearer form of arbitration - like the deals that the EU has with Switzerland and Ukraine - to reduce the likelihood of anything getting as far as the ECJ. This would be perfectly compatible with the spirit of the agreement.
6. At the moment, this is a theoretical problem. And in any case, there is already in the protocol a mechanism for the Joint Committee to try and resolve disputes.

5. On the European Court Justice, unlike the way in which checks are applied to goods entering NI, the Government cannot argue that the ECJ’s role has now become bigger or different compared to what it was when Boris Johnson declared this to be a really good deal.

4. But negotiations need trust, and trust is in very short supply because the Prime Minister is trying to remove aspects of the agreement that he signed up to only two years ago knowing perfectly well what they were.
3. There will now be a negotiation between the UK and the EU. Let’s hope that both sides enter into that in a spirit of compromise and goodwill.

2. The real test is how Northern Ireland businesses react. What they say will be important because they understand better than anyone else what those problems are and what they would be in future if there were no changes.

1. The EU proposals on the NI protocol look like a significant step forward. The EU has moved from saying in effect “the rules are the rules are the rules” to recognising that applying them fully in Northern Ireland would create unacceptable problems for NI and GB businesses.

10. Both sides need a deal - after all jumping off a cliff isn’t going to be good for anyone. 
What’s needed now is a willingness on both sides to sort this out in the interests of all our futures.

9. This would allow time to see whether the concerns – the UK view of sovereignty on the one hand and the EU fear that the UK will gain a competitive advantage over German, French and other countries’ firms on the other - is really something that we need to worry about.

8. One way of avoiding the problem for now would be to have a review clause; ie an agreement that after say 5 yrs both sides could look at these LPF rules and the link to the degree of access that the UK has been given to the EU single market and decide whether they are working.

7. The other issue is that because this arrangement will last for a very long time, both sides are trying to protect their interests and guard against something happening in future which they don’t want.

6. The areas of dispute are these. How do you identify whether different standards are in practice affecting fair competition? Who decides? And at what point in the process can one side take action against the other to ‘re-level’ the playing field?

5. The other consideration is that trust was undermined by the row over the Internal Market Bill. Seeking to renege on part of a Treaty you negotiated a year ago is not a very good idea, especially when you’re trying to negotiate a new Treaty with the same partners now.

4. In the Political Declaration both sides signed up to robust level playing field commitments to “prevent distortions of trade and unfair competitive advantages.” That’s why both the UK and the EU should want a mechanism for ensuring that the terms of trade remain fair.

3. But the issue is what happens if EU standards diverge from ours in the years ahead and vice versa. In other words, how do you make sure that the playing field that both sides run out onto on 1 Jan remains level in the years ahead?

2. It’s pretty clear now that the level playing field is the cause of the deadlock. It seems that the UK and the EU have already agreed a non-regression clause – ie that both sides won’t reduce existing standards on things like environmental protection and workers rights.

10.  I still think there will be one, but if it doesn’t happen then while, of course, the Prime Minister will blame the EU, the blunt truth is that he will have no-one to blame but himself.
9.  This is now all about political will. I think the vast majority of people in the country want a deal. So our message to the negotiators should be, keep going and please get an agreement.

8.  So what needs to happen in the very little time that remains? Both sides need to compromise. That’s how you get agreements. It cannot be impossible to find a way through on the level playing field or fisheries or how disputes will be resolved.

7.  Ministers know it too even though they pretend no deal is a good outcome. They’ve done the calculations which show a loss of future GDP. At a time when we’re already facing an economic crisis because of Covid, why on earth would you want to impose no deal on top of that?

6.  Businesses also know how damaging no deal would be. Just ask lamb or beef farmers or carmakers or the the British Retail Consortium which has calculated that no deal tariffs would add £3.1bn a year to the cost of importing food and drink from the EU.

5.  Firms know this. Week after week our select committee has heard how business will be made more costly, more difficult and more uncertain because of expensive duplication (eg chemicals registration), new red tape, the potential for border delays or simply lack of clarity.
4.  This is the first trade negotiation in British history in which the Government has gone into the talks knowing that it will come out with worse terms than what we have at the moment.
3.  ....and the claim that we could get the exact same benefits - will finally be exposed for what they were. Completely hollow.

2.  Either way, because any deal is likely to be thin (although avoiding tariffs is crucial) all those promises - one of the easiest trade deals in human history, we hold all the cards, there will be no downside to Brexit only a considerable upside....

10. And how will such policies to help those who run out of cash be administered in practice, given the very large number of people and businesses who may be affected at any one time?
9. The same questions about paying staff and bills will apply to businesses which see demand plummet and/or face bankruptcy. How does the Government propose to help them?

8. Some people simply won’t be able to pay bills so what is the Government’s plan about mortgage payments, council rent, council tax, utility bills, VAT and business rates in those circumstances? Is it going to cancel debts or say you don’t have to pay for the time being?

7. As this crisis unfolds, there will be quite a lot of people who will cease to have an income either because they are ill, or their employer has laid them off or because, as self-employed people, there isn’t any work coming in.
6. We need a minister to be given specific responsibility for the effort to ensure that more ventilators and ECMO machines are produced.

5. If a lot of elderly people have to self isolate in the near future, what are the plans for making sure they are looked out for, have enough food, etc ? Where should we direct queries from elderly people themselves or their concerned families about how this will work?

4. If there isn’t already, there should be an equivalent of COBRA in every local authority area bringing together all of those who are working very hard at the moment on trying to deal with the virus.

3. For example, why has the UK approach to testing changed? And why does it appear that we are now doing something different to what the WHO recommends? It would be good to hear the scientific explanation.

2. Getting communications right is crucial to public confidence.  We need a daily news conference led by the Chief Medical Officer and/or his deputy so that announcements can be made and questions answered about the rationale behind the policies to fight the virus.

Although @DExEUgov has now closed down, the Foreign Secretary was unable to tell me in the House of Commons just now which minister is responsible for the negotiations on our future relationship with the EU.
12. And in that same spirit, however we feel tonight, that is what we must now together do.

11. A final thought. Those of us who mourn tonight were often wrongly said to be pessimists about about our country’s future. I think the contrary is true for it is when we are confident about ourselves that we are able to reach out and engage with others.

10. And the EU’s future? It will evolve and we should wish it well. After all it has succeeded in doing something extraordinary in preventing a return to the conflicts of the past that claimed the lives of generations of young Europeans, including so many of our own citizens.
9. How can we best deal with all of these things? By working with others as we build alliances and promote our values.

8. Think about the great challenges we face as a world.  Tackling climate change. Trying to contain threats to peace and security.  Deciding the rules of international trade. Dealing with the movement of human beings across the globe or new disease outbreaks.

7.  For 47 years we chose to exercise our sovereignty in cooperation with other European countries and the need to do that will not disappear tomorrow. So let us find ways of counteracting the loss of influence that is one of the consequence of leaving.

6. There has been so much debate about sovereignty, but it’s how we use it that matters. We never ceased to be a sovereign country, as the influence we had as a member state and the fact that we are now leaving both show.

5. Britain is a great country and national pride is something that we can celebrate together. But that is different from a nationalism which divides - us versus them. So let us embrace our interdependence as human beings who share a small and fragile planet.
4. This will be the most important priority over the next 11 months because all of us, especially businesses, will need to know what future we should plan for.

3. Our friends, neighbours and trading partners across the English Channel will still be our friends, neighbours and trading partners and that’s why we need to negotiate a close economic relationship for the years ahead.
2. Britain was always a pragmatic rather than an ideological EU member state. We joined late and left early, but we will still be Europeans.

1. A thread not about why leaving the EU is a bad idea. We’ve made that argument and we haven’t changed our minds, but we lost. It’s happening. So instead, a few reflections on this moment for those who will be mourning and celebrating in almost equal measure tonight.
